Galaxies marked in orange meet the dual red-sequence criterion, i.e. they fall within 3\u03c3 of the cluster red sequence in both the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> and the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. Galaxies highlighted in red are spectroscopically confirmed cluster members.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=vYtNCsK8lC~wIwYwaJKV~gGZMbayW3aZHMr8d6y5JPk4gAg5yq-KI2BDGol0w~KSCSUYVBXMsh6RusL5su4TOCW8nCTk1soj7klqW2Qzi5P~4RCMAblXhOjMXNm6zRBm8MYw1scReJG-jmYInTpW4ca45rxSeF3hhlX5zfAjvPottgzAxS15fNEBCkIiu8uloZGpps7eZa-wUp9wDbxLVeY6yK4c56CSeNUTTUYluDSg0zNdk2TXXwuem26ce~v4UejoDYZmbJnxXVeb-AbLkAlx7YNwWvu-zf7-M3TO4xv~EN0GgFRiJwugfMy2-IzMOq6liP-~X4rUuS31CZ5ejQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour diagram for galaxies in the A2744 field, as defined in Fig.\u00a01. Galaxies marked in orange meet the dual red-sequence criterion, i.e. they fall within 3\u03c3 of the cluster red sequence in both the (mF606W\u00a0\u2212\u00a0mF814W) versus mF814W and the (mF435W\u00a0\u2212\u00a0mF606W) versus mF814W colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. Galaxies highlighted in red are spectroscopically confirmed cluster members.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991921/stu1395fig10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991921\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=wPzd9~5~3Q5sEzbtBmgoC-VQ3H8gmcOw5PnHdyfroClh5ezH~JAeMO9H1ca08wROSGKKcQaD-AcGnDVuC2rztJ9ZLbBa43kHfYjJeKUbYLRFQAdFvtlW-42KGZ3P18qYLkilI5HRkw8r2EUjrFQfyurlGybmInoO4Qnja6wUCGh0UFB0IpXjrJmz3PDBxhSTNJVo7mM3n~oghV9dFTaYnXl3eES5m4Aa3d2nzDVtQ3lFDhmjTt3TwE9U98LcT-NzjuS1MaAsV5PYXDalDkkudUK-f2X3xICtvjjWV5~CDYiBKUrz-GEqsdkVwGK3HCoZzx0lc27TmMHOUKB6~KYgtw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991921&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour\u2013colour diagram for galaxies in the A2744 field, as defined in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Galaxies marked in orange meet the dual red-sequence criterion, i.e. they fall within 3\u03c3 of the cluster red sequence in both the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> and the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. Galaxies highlighted in red are spectroscopically confirmed cluster members.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991922 id=\"91991922\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>Model parametrization</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Producing a magnification map involves solving the lens equation for light rays originating from distant sources and deflected by the massive foreground cluster. This is ultimately an inversion problem for which several sets of codes and approaches have been developed independently. Our collaboration uses <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>2</sup></a> (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), an algorithm we developed collectively over the years. In this software, the cluster mass distribution can be described as a combination of physically motivated mass components, both for the individual galaxies and the smoother, large-scale haloes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a basis function for our models, we adopt the dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (dPIE, also known as truncated PIEMD), which corresponds to an isothermal profile with two characteristic radii: a core radius <em>r</em><sub>core</sub> (producing a flattening of the mass distribution at the centre), and a cut radius <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub> (producing a drop-off of the mass distribution on large scales). More details on the dPIE parametrization are given in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This method has the advantage that the geometrical parameters of the galaxy-scale components (centre, ellipticity, orientation) can be directly related to the shape parameters measured from the light distribution of cluster galaxies in our photometric catalogue. In order to limit the number of free parameters in our model, we use the <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band as the reference band for these shape measurements and determine the three other parameters of each galaxy's dPIE description (central velocity dispersion \u03c3, core, and cut radii) from scaling relations based on the galaxy's luminosity <em>L</em> relative to <em>L</em>*. We set <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm core}^*$|</span> = 0.15\u00a0kpc for all models, but optimize both \u03c3* and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|\u2060</span>, following Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) and Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), respectively. We adopt a flat prior for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{\\rm cut}^*$|</span> in the range [1-100]\u00a0kpc, and a Gaussian prior \u03c3*\u00a0=\u00a0158\u00a0\u00b1\u00a027\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, as demonstrated by Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>) for a sample of <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.2 clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At present, the prevailing modelling approach is to assign a small-scale dark matter clump to each cluster galaxy in our catalogue, and a large-scale dark matter clump to prominent concentrations of cluster galaxies. This technique has proven very reliable and provides results in mass distributions in reasonably good agreement with theoretical predictions from high-resolution cosmological <em>N</em>-body simulations (Natarajan &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Natarajan, De Lucia &amp; Springel\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This explicit one-to-one correspondence between mass and light is less accurate, however, in the outer regions of clusters where the galaxy distribution is sparser, and strong-lensing constraints are unavailable. The solution is to combine strong-lensing constraints near the cluster cores with a weak-lensing analysis on larger scales.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991927 id=\"91991927\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>Likelihoods definition</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For each Frontier Field cluster, we optimize two parametric models: an SL (strong-lensing) model solely based on the strong-lensing constraints presented in Section\u00a03.1, and an SL+WL model combining the strong-lensing constraints with a weak-lensing analysis, as described in Section\u00a04.3. We proceed in two steps for each cluster: we start by creating an SL model, optimized in the image plane, and determine the parametrization (number of clumps and individual galaxies to be optimized). In this case, we used the following likelihood definition <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathcal {L}_{{\\rm SLimg}} = \\prod ^{M,N_i}_{i,j} \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\sigma _{{\\rm SL}}^2}} \\exp \\left( -\\frac{1}{2} \\frac{|\\theta _{ij} - \\langle \\theta _i \\rangle |^2}{\\sigma _{{\\rm SL}}^2} \\right),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where \u3008\u03b8<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u3009 is the estimated image position for system <em>i</em>, based on the barycentre of the multiple positions in the source plane.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We then use the same parametrization to optimize the SL+WL model, this time performing the optimization in the source plane which is less computing-time intensive. To this end, we define the total likelihood <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L} = \\mathcal {L}_{{\\rm SLsrc}} \\times \\mathcal {L}_{{\\rm WL}}$|</span> as the product of the strong- and the weak-lensing likelihoods. The strong-lensing likelihood in the source plane is, in turn, defined as the product of <em>M</em> systems of <em>N</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> multiple-image likelihoods <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\mathcal {L}_{{\\rm SLsrc}} = \\prod ^{M,N_i}_{i,j} \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\mu _{ij}^{-1} \\sigma _{{\\rm SL}}^2}} \\exp \\left( -\\frac{1}{2} \\frac{|\\beta _{ij} - \\langle \\beta _i \\rangle |^2}{\\mu _{ij}^{-1} \\sigma _{{\\rm SL}}^2} \\right),\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where \u03b2<sub><em>ij</em></sub> are the source positions of the multiple images, and \u3008\u03b2<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u3009 are the barycentre of these positions for system <em>i</em>. For each image, the positional uncertainty in the image-plane \u03c3<sub>SL</sub> is multiplied by the amplification \u03bc<sub><em>ij</em></sub>. We conduct this optimization in the source plane as the much more involved computations of an image-plane optimization would have unduly strained the available computing resources. We find that, for strong-lensing data sets only, source- and image-plane optimizations yield similar reconstructions for the clusters studied in this work.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Finally, the weak-lensing likelihood is defined as the product of the <em>L</em> weak-lensing source likelihoods <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\mathcal {L}_{{\\rm WL}} = \\prod ^{L}_i \\frac{1}{\\sqrt{2 \\pi \\sigma _{\\epsilon _i}^2}} \\exp \\left( -\\frac{1}{2} \\frac{|\\epsilon ^s_i|^2}{\\sigma _{\\epsilon _i}^2} \\right),\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\epsilon ^s_i|$|</span> is the module of the predicted source ellipticity obtained from the amplification matrix <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sf{A}$|</span> and the second brightness moments of each image <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sf {Q}$|\u2060</span>, through the equation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sf {Q}^s_i = \\sf{A} \\sf {Q} \\sf{A}^T$|</span> (Bartelmann\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). The ellipticity is defined as <em>e</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>)/(<em>a</em><sup>2</sup>\u00a0+\u00a0<em>b</em><sup>2</sup>), where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the eigenvalues of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sf {Q}$|\u2060</span>. This matrix transformation is valid both in the weak- and in the strong-lensing regime. In this work, we assume <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\epsilon _i}^2 = \\sigma _{\\rm int}^2 + \\sigma _{\\rm meas_i}^2$|\u2060</span>, i.e. the variance is the quadratic sum of the intrinsic ellipticity and the shape measurement errors for each galaxy.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">By adopting this two-step approach, we avoid the possibility of reaching a local minimum in the source-plane optimization: in the SL+WL model, group- and cluster-scale haloes are mainly optimized on large scales based on weak-lensing constraints, while their centre and shape parameters remain similar to those of the SL model.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991932 id=\"91991932\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991933 id=\"91991933\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Parametric model</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of large-scale clumps included in each cluster was chosen to minimize the number of free parameters while reproducing the multiple-image sets to an accuracy of better than 0.8\u2009arcsec. The number of large-scale clumps finally adopted for our models varies from 1 (for Abell S1063) to 5 (for Abell 2744 and MACS\u00a0J0717). As shown in Section\u00a03.1, Abell 2744 features a bimodal mass distribution on large scales, but also includes a number of group-scale structures at the edges of the ACS field of view. For the even more complex system MACS\u00a0J0717, the distribution of cluster light shows peaks at the location of each large-scale clump (see the discussion in Limousin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to these large-scale haloes, a few individual galaxies are explicitly included in our lens models, as their adopted properties have a strong influence on the location of nearby multiple-imaged systems. This is true for two galaxies in Abell 2744, two galaxies in Abell 370 (as already found by Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), as well as for a massive foreground galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.1 in the field of MACS\u00a0J0416 which does not follow the same scaling relations as the cluster members.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each cluster, we describe the large-scale potentials (identified as DM1 to DM5), the aforementioned added galaxy-scale potentials (GAL1 and GAL2), and the scaling relations for cluster members, presented for a L* galaxy. The optimized source redshift for all multiple-image systems without spectroscopic redshift is summarized in the last column of Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The resulting parameters of the combined (SL+WL) models are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl8\" data-open=\"tbl8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The parameters of the combined models agree with those of the best-fitting SL models within the 2\u03c3 uncertainties; the resulting \u03c72 values are very similar too. As expected, the most massive components detected by our weak-lensing analysis were thus already present in our SL parametrization.</p>                        <a id=\"91991937\" scrollto-destination=\"91991937\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong-lensing features identified in the existing <em>HST</em> images of A\u00a02744. Spectroscopic redshifts are listed under <em>z</em><sub>prior</sub> where available; other constraints used during the optimization process are quoted as a range, enclosed in square brackets.</p></div> </div><div parameters of the mass components in each cluster for the models optimized with the combination of strong-lensing and weak-lensing constraints. no-formula-id\">|$833^{+58}_{-6}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DM2\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-2.5^{+ 0.8}_{ -0.0}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$35.6^{+ 1.5}_{ -2.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.38^{+ 0.04}_{-0.05}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$-89.6^{+ 2.8}_{ -2.4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$155^{+9}_{-12}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>[1000]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1128^{+37}_{-51}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GAL1\u00a0</td><td>[\u22120.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.30]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221281.9]\u00a0</td><td>[0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$34^{+4}_{-3}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$129^{+22}_{-22}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>GAL2\u00a0</td><td>[7.9]\u00a0</td><td>[\u22129.8]\u00a0</td><td>[0.26]\u00a0</td><td>[25.7]\u00a0</td><td>[0]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$28^{+5}_{-4}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$64^{+11}_{-16}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>L* galaxy\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$61^{+21}_{-5}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$116^{+16}_{-8}$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91991944\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991945 id=\"91991945\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>Output maps and error estimation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The parametric models are adjusted with <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> in a Bayesian way, i.e. we probe their posterior probability density with a MCMC sampler (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This process allows us to easily and reliably estimate the errors on derived quantities such as the amplification maps and the mass maps. For each cluster, we use 200 randomly selected models to sample the posterior-probability distribution of each parameter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">High-resolution mass maps (integrated over the line of sight) were produced for each of these models, and then integrated as a function of the radial distance from their barycentre. The resulting average integrated mass and 1\u03c3 dispersion (computed over the 200 maps per cluster) are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>. All FF clusters are found to be very massive, reaching integrated masses at 500\u00a0kpc radius between 4 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> (for MACS\u00a0J0416) and 10<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> for the most massive cluster MACS\u00a0J0717. At <em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0100\u00a0kpc, all six mass profiles look very similar, the sole exception being the highly concentrated and fully relaxed system Abell S1063, whose brightest cluster galaxy is almost exactly centred within a single large-scale dark matter halo.</p>                        <a id=\"91991948\" scrollto-destination=\"91991948\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=OjG4xa-QVoTNuRmedjxOV3gkPGFNl9N7LLrnpBg~dZlTxT-Xu2rMWnSPwDOAdX~3JjOCTMlhE1eAvNr89bzgndiGo9lFO2pdq3agswi9O9dkqLBT2Suukat8gBSIOLcM-V~rme7aybWIf~5wnnby61nL~KvXhYaNYfBS6ukJdCof7Q4LzJUQY5vGv8MXlGPNGHmy6ht0aSBnHqVi-V8lXYBii3m0xBp3dkEn9fRFB1KK8sBxImHBV6ECNULppAlJrjNTFXifIn-h4z790EMakD5njiNvCI4qMtGSWezdRX7nPU3DRdI4EyW48mpqmk89Q1GCVi-ImPqQ6MzgHh0RXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Total integrated mass as a function of the projected distance from the barycentre. Each colour-hatched region corresponds to the average and 1\u03c3 dispersion on the integrated mass in each FF cluster. The bottom panel shows a zoom over the 100\u00a0&lt;\u00a0r\u00a0&lt;\u00a0500\u00a0kpc region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991948/stu1395fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991948\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=XerYL2QGR9068fq89~CE6zZncYLAcw9CWQcCNVyqDeyknlC-ttZ78uDcOXjIISMKVlVb~pgtsjycxnDzZ8e9jNRGM7-V4txHXim3m1PQM7MWOEFh7ZcFnYc1mLjrYxKVEzJcxmqnr14OTgrwZN6z3cGPJevZYAKsyhZ-xUHs4pJt3rXE-h3zHgf4EiScVZonLwNje1ZEwcKGMtKTOWm-CyUIezQj-kw~7WEmgGL5QnbI31PzaJeXghwT7tsTXNznVK4Yf-HV93xynU5rwOSiuexVQIbvjwY9388wWYinxyurjCeT0QnMyrY1ErisT2mKxiW69m3yubY6~sx3DHCgeg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991948&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Total integrated mass as a function of the projected distance from the barycentre. Each colour-hatched region corresponds to the average and 1\u03c3 dispersion on the integrated mass in each FF cluster. The bottom panel shows a zoom over the 100\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0500\u00a0kpc region.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=OjG4xa-QVoTNuRmedjxOV3gkPGFNl9N7LLrnpBg~dZlTxT-Xu2rMWnSPwDOAdX~3JjOCTMlhE1eAvNr89bzgndiGo9lFO2pdq3agswi9O9dkqLBT2Suukat8gBSIOLcM-V~rme7aybWIf~5wnnby61nL~KvXhYaNYfBS6ukJdCof7Q4LzJUQY5vGv8MXlGPNGHmy6ht0aSBnHqVi-V8lXYBii3m0xBp3dkEn9fRFB1KK8sBxImHBV6ECNULppAlJrjNTFXifIn-h4z790EMakD5njiNvCI4qMtGSWezdRX7nPU3DRdI4EyW48mpqmk89Q1GCVi-ImPqQ6MzgHh0RXw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Total integrated mass as a function of the projected distance from the barycentre. Each colour-hatched region corresponds to the average and 1\u03c3 dispersion on the integrated mass in each FF cluster. The bottom panel shows a zoom over the 100\u00a0&lt;\u00a0r\u00a0&lt;\u00a0500\u00a0kpc region.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991948/stu1395fig11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991948\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=XerYL2QGR9068fq89~CE6zZncYLAcw9CWQcCNVyqDeyknlC-ttZ78uDcOXjIISMKVlVb~pgtsjycxnDzZ8e9jNRGM7-V4txHXim3m1PQM7MWOEFh7ZcFnYc1mLjrYxKVEzJcxmqnr14OTgrwZN6z3cGPJevZYAKsyhZ-xUHs4pJt3rXE-h3zHgf4EiScVZonLwNje1ZEwcKGMtKTOWm-CyUIezQj-kw~7WEmgGL5QnbI31PzaJeXghwT7tsTXNznVK4Yf-HV93xynU5rwOSiuexVQIbvjwY9388wWYinxyurjCeT0QnMyrY1ErisT2mKxiW69m3yubY6~sx3DHCgeg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991948&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Total integrated mass as a function of the projected distance from the barycentre. Each colour-hatched region corresponds to the average and 1\u03c3 dispersion on the integrated mass in each FF cluster. The bottom panel shows a zoom over the 100\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>r</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a0500\u00a0kpc region.</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We applied the same procedure to create amplification maps and accompanying error maps in all six fields, assuming fiducial source redshifts of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01, 2, 4, and 9. Examples are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. These maps can also be extrapolated to the locations of the blank fields for the benefit of the larger extragalactic community. Amplification maps at other source redshifts can be derived based on the convergence \u03ba and shear \u03b3 maps before normalization by the geometrical distance ratio between the cluster and the source. For a given image position and source redshift, one can derive the magnification \u03bc as follows: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n1/\\mu = (1-(D_{\\rm LS}/D_{\\rm S})\\ \\kappa )^2-((D_{\\rm LS}/D_{\\rm S})\\gamma )^2,\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where DLS and DS are the angular diameter distance between the lens and the source, and between the observer and the source, respectively.</div>                        <a id=\"91991950\" scrollto-destination=\"91991950\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=2zC923yo9ErrXhgSkKqewTcAVv6VDcSLg8Vj6BZWzrYKmeBB~AQbet~sC1ZFlpdD6-4~jriNlAsE1qYpepWktnCyn34wpEZYfGuQVm8D--Ogv3EGfP1dhI8Qwi5p4DIfBYv~Vtu7IiHpOhjOcUDqgLM5IKUPoQYbiIUKFA1ENJUYFQm~xYeAlF21iV8Ze7awb4gO~xzpZpuxy4EYNider3hmWGhpBQyv1iBQODtTqxCsFV5dwCZGyfmNz7ECkCms0q5yzOIHUuz8l1OWcdW1HCDDRBZwscAHENEFI070rcVF0aNLTD1uAM1YZ3RhkqlgVaWoeQrhjQYOV0mCEssNVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnification map (left-hand panel) and error map (right-hand panel) produced in the central region of Abell 2744 for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a09. Contours show a relative error of 10, 20, and 50\u00a0per\u2009cent\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991950/stu1395fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991950\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=2gE2XLvJxT22md8qkVDhRHcoTifR70VuyQoEAUYH1RLYkSlfROw34K4uwwx8SDpDmyl1p6E8sDEYuxwgQ~CpF4ccf-LSToqq6FH0xr3LD0odgkKsCZ-Jj5LcFGcYJPdce7eciTsRxtoRdy2vzHabsrvXK8TcCotiYEM2zxJqrwevgHSbK~JShQymT12e4Xalb5Y3~aKMF61bF4DMmPrmFjl7llTOCVaTHBPj8IqVQH0DNkyqgF4C3-3rE5v52G5BExxtdO4CJ0fKfkhf0NtxAaX9oBVbFs0ruTkEt-IctA3PjNU80HxgNBNFPBkSxulfbqlZNK~iIBbMU2NPlf8~2g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991950&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnification map (left-hand panel) and error map (right-hand panel) produced in the central region of Abell 2744 for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09. Contours show a relative error of 10, 20, and 50\u00a0per\u2009cent</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=2zC923yo9ErrXhgSkKqewTcAVv6VDcSLg8Vj6BZWzrYKmeBB~AQbet~sC1ZFlpdD6-4~jriNlAsE1qYpepWktnCyn34wpEZYfGuQVm8D--Ogv3EGfP1dhI8Qwi5p4DIfBYv~Vtu7IiHpOhjOcUDqgLM5IKUPoQYbiIUKFA1ENJUYFQm~xYeAlF21iV8Ze7awb4gO~xzpZpuxy4EYNider3hmWGhpBQyv1iBQODtTqxCsFV5dwCZGyfmNz7ECkCms0q5yzOIHUuz8l1OWcdW1HCDDRBZwscAHENEFI070rcVF0aNLTD1uAM1YZ3RhkqlgVaWoeQrhjQYOV0mCEssNVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Magnification map (left-hand panel) and error map (right-hand panel) produced in the central region of Abell 2744 for a source at z\u00a0=\u00a09. Contours show a relative error of 10, 20, and 50\u00a0per\u2009cent\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991950/stu1395fig12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991950\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=2gE2XLvJxT22md8qkVDhRHcoTifR70VuyQoEAUYH1RLYkSlfROw34K4uwwx8SDpDmyl1p6E8sDEYuxwgQ~CpF4ccf-LSToqq6FH0xr3LD0odgkKsCZ-Jj5LcFGcYJPdce7eciTsRxtoRdy2vzHabsrvXK8TcCotiYEM2zxJqrwevgHSbK~JShQymT12e4Xalb5Y3~aKMF61bF4DMmPrmFjl7llTOCVaTHBPj8IqVQH0DNkyqgF4C3-3rE5v52G5BExxtdO4CJ0fKfkhf0NtxAaX9oBVbFs0ruTkEt-IctA3PjNU80HxgNBNFPBkSxulfbqlZNK~iIBbMU2NPlf8~2g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991950&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Magnification map (left-hand panel) and error map (right-hand panel) produced in the central region of Abell 2744 for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09. Contours show a relative error of 10, 20, and 50\u00a0per\u2009cent</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The best-fitting <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> models, mass maps, amplification maps, and relative errors, as well as the 200 convergence and shear maps for each cluster, are made publicly available on the Frontier Fields website <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/\" target=\"_blank\">http://archive.stsci.edu/prepds/frontier/lensmodels/</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is worth mentioning that the relative errors computed from the MCMC samples are only statistical errors and do not include systematics due to the assumptions made in the models. In order to estimate the level of these systematics, we have performed three specific tests, where we re-optimized the six mass models under different assumptions: (a) we selected only 10 robust multiple systems per cluster, i.e. either spectroscopically confirmed and/or among the brightest systems in agreement with various lensing groups, as strong-lensing constraints; (b) we increased the error measurement on the shear values by 50\u00a0per\u2009cent; and (c) we increased by \u0394<em>z</em> = 0.5 the distribution assumed for background sources in the weak-lensing constraints. By comparing the magnification maps at very high redshift, we observed an average variation in magnification within the ACS field of view by 0.1\u20130.35 mag for test (a), by 0.1 mag for test (b), and by 0.05\u20130.1 mag for test (c), depending on the complexity of the cluster model. As expected due to its strong influence on high magnification values, the robustness of multiple systems used as constraints produces the stronger systematics. This justifies the need for future comparison between the magnification maps produced by the different modelling teams on the same simulated cluster.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991953 id=\"91991953\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the key goals of the Frontier Fields initiative is to improve the statistics on faint distant galaxies observed during the epoch of reionization. The expected extent of this improvement can be assessed using our best models for each cluster, which yield the gravitational magnification for high-redshift galaxies in the central region covered by deep observations with both ACS and WFC3. In doing so, we adopt <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07 as a reference source redshift, noting though that the change in magnification is typically very small between <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07 and 10.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A first estimate of the relative lensing efficiency of the six HFF clusters can be obtained by comparing their peak magnification values. These are reached close to the <em>critical lines</em>, which are shown in red in Figs\u00a02\u20138. The solid angles over which magnifications of \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a05 and \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010 are attained in each cluster range from 0.8 to 2.9\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> and are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. While the largest areas with significant magnification are provided by MACS\u00a0J0717, Abell 370, and Abell S1063, all FF clusters are similarly efficient lenses to within a factor of 2.</p>                        <a id=\"91991956\" scrollto-destination=\"91991956\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl9\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl9\" data-id=\"tbl9\"><span class=\"label\">Table 9.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing efficiency of the HFF clusters using various metrics. From left to right: fraction of the area in the image plane amplified by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a05, by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010, and covered by multiple images, and the surface area in the source plane magnified by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a03. All areas relate to the overlapping region with foreseen deep ACS and WFC3 observations.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03a9<sub><em>i</em></sub>(\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a05)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03a9<sub><em>i</em></sub>(\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03a9<sub><em>i</em></sub>(mult)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub>\u03bc</sub>(\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a03)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>arcmin<sup>2</sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell S1063\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0</td><td>0.26\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl9\" data-id=\"tbl9\"><span class=\"label\">Table 9.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing efficiency of the HFF clusters using various metrics. From left to right: fraction of the area in the image plane amplified by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a05, by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010, and covered by multiple images, and the surface area in the source plane magnified by \u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a03. All areas relate to the overlapping region with foreseen deep ACS and WFC3 observations.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03a9<sub><em>i</em></sub>(\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a010)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03a9<sub><em>i</em></sub>(mult)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03c3<sub>\u03bc</sub>(\u03bc\u00a0&gt;\u00a03)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(per cent)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>arcmin<sup>2</sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell 2744\u00a0</td><td>36\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0</td><td>0.41\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0416\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0</td><td>17\u00a0</td><td>46\u00a0</td><td>0.22\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0717\u00a0</td><td>48\u00a0</td><td>28\u00a0</td><td>90\u00a0</td><td>0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J1149\u00a0</td><td>38\u00a0</td><td>20\u00a0</td><td>39\u00a0</td><td>0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell 370\u00a0</td><td>61\u00a0</td><td>38\u00a0</td><td>65\u00a0</td><td>0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell S1063\u00a0</td><td>47\u00a0</td><td>25\u00a0</td><td>55\u00a0</td><td>0.26\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91991956\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">One shortcoming of peak magnification as a metric for measuring lensing efficiency is that it provides no information about image multiplicity, i.e. the frequency of the various lensing configurations (the creation of 1, 3, 5, or more images from a single source), which can vary from cluster to cluster. We therefore compute a second important cluster attribute, namely the sky area covered by multiple images in the image plane. This area is related to the number of multiple images expected to be found in each cluster. The sky area within which multiple images are observed encloses the critical line but has a more circular shape, covering between 1.5 and 4.2\u00a0arcmin<sup>2</sup> for the six HFF clusters (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). Based on these figures, we expect to find multiple images of high-redshift sources across almost the entire solid angle (91\u00a0per\u2009cent) of the WFC3 pointing on MACS\u00a0J0717. Again, Abell 370 and Abell S1063 show the second- and third-highest fraction of WFC3 solid angle conducive to multiple-image creation. The lower values for Abell 2744, MACS\u00a0J0416, and MACS\u00a0J1149 are caused by their higher elongation and orientation within the WFC3 footprint on the sky.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The combined effect of magnification and image multiplicity is best assessed in the source plane. To this end, we take advantage of <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>'s capability to provide source-plane magnification maps based on, for a given source position, the most magnified image. Inverting the combined ACS+WFC3 aperture yields the source-plane magnification maps shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>, where the regions of highest magnification now clearly delineate the <em>caustic lines</em>. The strong variation in shape and surface area of these maps directly reflects the fraction of the respective HFF field that falls within the critical line. Indeed, the total surface area in the source plane above a given magnification factor is directly proportional to the unlensed comoving volume covered at high redshift with this magnification (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">14</a>). As a result, Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) proposed to use \u03c3<sub>\u03bc</sub>, the total surface area in the source plane above \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a03, as a measurement of the efficiency of the lensing configuration to magnify high-redshift galaxies. These values are also reported in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl9\" data-open=\"tbl9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"91991959\" scrollto-destination=\"91991959\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig13.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=O7A3bn91Dvii74d5nYCLL1PJ8n6uHZ0yJlnr5SbEXmi~rl0DLTqqskTESxm~HeAUUaD1EVSBq5pwCb2yH0hQnIPiQzwz85uRCRKUrx5A6XHlNjnA7QXNszCbiv462wMNFp9JZYFvL2m5pqLh7R9PdcxEsptIxRD5Tum7knUoYnku8OTwzS5QMZrjVxJsKocKNe6VUZKiDfT8STMQ~0EhaG2WlEEp3vyScpFgKpHIp3hfLJ-eoyorhfofvsRcYfmaTABskYgWYaKeD5bDWOIfvR0d36dmJgofBcdUzgq8xBa2LZ8qRVmQCHmwmw3i4RfIvwuRt6psJwp0Fcu3l5MdQg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Source-plane magnification maps corresponding to the expected ACS+WFC3 coverage of the Frontier Field clusters. class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991960/stu1395fig14.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig14.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991960\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig14.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=T0CiN95pmuRGF3N8XxrNle3ekGHG1kjqrSlN7Fc5DAqIsS~D~XdNr4fj6X8h8N4g-l8HiJRId85P9CGdlULd6Kc3e1nQObDgw0XJx-HpXGs-DC8tNmmisamSrIJcZXssXFyRPJl0vS7KJMwHz3UF~hHAubh5xKEjoRow39MlGkbOB4OSEWxocUrVcLQ9XDc7hvbtlGYH1-tlBDpPUSyImil0B-okpW8CZ4csf~MSEFuDSEitv5D9mzys8EWoUCEnsKKRrKA0LKLOV436O~SQjGdXlfYAsb6Fvaoa5brSDKxHCxGFwTU3Pt7M7PcDvCxw8qTksAcXwuDBZanZ0Noq5w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991960&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig14.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Surface area in the source plane covered by the ACS+WFC3 region (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig14\" data-open=\"fig14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>) at a magnification above a given threshold \u03bc.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we use the recent estimates on the UV luminosity function at high redshift from Bouwens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to predict the number of high-redshift dropouts at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a07, <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09, and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a011 expected to be detected in the FF data, as a function of their observed (lensed) magnitude (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>). We assume an unbiased selection over a redshift interval \u0394\u2009<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01 centred on each redshift. The predictions at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09 and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a011 use the fitting formula given by Bouwens et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) for the evolution of the Schechter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1976</a>) parameters of the luminosity function at high redshift.</p>                        <a id=\"91991962\" scrollto-destination=\"91991962\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=yJa~sktGUCkrcuCtt-xFRuqj2MZUZULI-IEUW3N5o8Mnl60NdG7CP4RAUs4hW327FyyWsSVAp55C5~L28KaiijRAwxS3L~-EgzG9GHJ3f1AXBiaYV1NdVGRPFithseK9lH1RHkCeR0hhEGv9HyFGCIDnrF5Cv1zqs3e70a9TWvdWcE20m1QC8~VeI~9PLHgUzRWspI9~OmTU6mw5RdCMQgK1u03-lX-svu84BvxlSxOwSIQwHTDGcTkqPexaVKsvAbdvc9NFWyyyUYv0fHLQ-w8zBwDM1A7E8BduUD0x8yepkUJgdM9s9ORTvbCiCG0sDAu-aQp9DuMJLNK0VkEVxg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Predicted number of high-redshift sources at z\u00a0=\u00a07 (top), z\u00a0=\u00a09 (middle) and z\u00a0=\u00a011 (bottom panel), per redshift interval \u0394\u2009z\u00a0=\u00a01, assuming a blank field with typical errors (bottom black solid and dotted lines), each of the six FF clusters in turn (same colours as Fig.\u00a013), and the sum over all fields (top solid black line). Overplotted as a solid-dotted line in each panel are the total intrinsic counts (per magnitude bin, corrected for magnification) expected in the FF observations. The dashed limit and the grey region mark the limiting magnitudes for HFF and the UDF, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991962/stu1395fig15.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991962\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=Hc~QWzCjCpQgWBPy18HG5QEWBe0zmF870yH7CSYWvLgCMu8Tfj1od1j2tSNm-4liCBlimw5s38jh3K7C8IxtZkruynZ~tdzi-TssO1yYdaZL8H7LDZTMZsEkptiMlzD0xGmnq7JwKQsaaM1J12Mz97rKetR8~szNOt2m3GPjBhgFKDZ23m0EoHyVdEAVaOMGeXxNlxI1QffJMhM3QsxWAURcLTYJYgzCVNospuHA4Wb2vkQWE88tP7Cvfkyogf3Umlq83PH8TKvSJgrEVLmLJQ58~wSdhVZglBdA56q1dKTCN3FBgiJeq0kk-zIdfUb6jzBcsILEUSnx9LpzoBs6bQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991962&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted number of high-redshift sources at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07 (top), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (middle) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a011 (bottom panel), per redshift interval \u0394\u2009<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01, assuming a blank field with typical errors (bottom black solid and dotted lines), each of the six FF clusters in turn (same colours as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>), and the sum over all fields (top solid black line). Overplotted as a solid-dotted line in each panel are the total intrinsic counts (per magnitude bin, corrected for magnification) expected in the FF observations. The dashed limit and the grey region mark the limiting magnitudes for HFF and the UDF, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig15\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=yJa~sktGUCkrcuCtt-xFRuqj2MZUZULI-IEUW3N5o8Mnl60NdG7CP4RAUs4hW327FyyWsSVAp55C5~L28KaiijRAwxS3L~-EgzG9GHJ3f1AXBiaYV1NdVGRPFithseK9lH1RHkCeR0hhEGv9HyFGCIDnrF5Cv1zqs3e70a9TWvdWcE20m1QC8~VeI~9PLHgUzRWspI9~OmTU6mw5RdCMQgK1u03-lX-svu84BvxlSxOwSIQwHTDGcTkqPexaVKsvAbdvc9NFWyyyUYv0fHLQ-w8zBwDM1A7E8BduUD0x8yepkUJgdM9s9ORTvbCiCG0sDAu-aQp9DuMJLNK0VkEVxg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Predicted number of high-redshift sources at z\u00a0=\u00a07 (top), z\u00a0=\u00a09 (middle) and z\u00a0=\u00a011 (bottom panel), per redshift interval \u0394\u2009z\u00a0=\u00a01, assuming a blank field with typical errors (bottom black solid and dotted lines), each of the six FF clusters in turn (same colours as Fig.\u00a013), and the sum over all fields (top solid black line). Overplotted as a solid-dotted line in each panel are the total intrinsic counts (per magnitude bin, corrected for magnification) expected in the FF observations. The dashed limit and the grey region mark the limiting magnitudes for HFF and the UDF, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991962/stu1395fig15.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991962\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig15.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=Hc~QWzCjCpQgWBPy18HG5QEWBe0zmF870yH7CSYWvLgCMu8Tfj1od1j2tSNm-4liCBlimw5s38jh3K7C8IxtZkruynZ~tdzi-TssO1yYdaZL8H7LDZTMZsEkptiMlzD0xGmnq7JwKQsaaM1J12Mz97rKetR8~szNOt2m3GPjBhgFKDZ23m0EoHyVdEAVaOMGeXxNlxI1QffJMhM3QsxWAURcLTYJYgzCVNospuHA4Wb2vkQWE88tP7Cvfkyogf3Umlq83PH8TKvSJgrEVLmLJQ58~wSdhVZglBdA56q1dKTCN3FBgiJeq0kk-zIdfUb6jzBcsILEUSnx9LpzoBs6bQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991962&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig15.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Predicted number of high-redshift sources at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07 (top), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 (middle) and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a011 (bottom panel), per redshift interval \u0394\u2009<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01, assuming a blank field with typical errors (bottom black solid and dotted lines), each of the six FF clusters in turn (same colours as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig13\" data-open=\"fig13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">13</a>), and the sum over all fields (top solid black line). Overplotted as a solid-dotted line in each panel are the total intrinsic counts (per magnitude bin, corrected for magnification) expected in the FF observations. The dashed limit and the grey region mark the limiting magnitudes for HFF and the UDF, respectively.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected number counts at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a07 demonstrate the advantage provided by cluster lenses compared to a blank field of the same sky coverage. The significant increase of bright sources thanks to gravitational lensing causes a <em>positive magnification bias</em> at observed AB magnitudes\u2009&lt;\u200927, owing to the steep slope of the bright end of the UV luminosity function (Maizy et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This bright-end boost in the number counts exceeds a factor of 3 at mag\u2009&lt;\u200926, which is the typical limit for spectroscopic follow-up with current 8\u201310m class telescopes. The effect is even stronger at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09 and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a011 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig15\" data-open=\"fig15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">15</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The above predictions have already been tested by the deep near-infrared observations of the HFF cluster A2744, performed at the end of 2013. Although ACS observations of matching depth are still lacking, the first searches for high-redshift galaxies behind this cluster have independently identified 15 dropouts at <em>z</em> \u223c 6-7 down to an AB magnitude of <em>J</em>\u00a0=\u00a028 (Atek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and 18 dropouts at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a07 down to an AB magnitude <em>H</em>\u00a0=\u00a029 (Laporte et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Zheng et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). These numbers are slightly higher than the predictions for <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a07 and <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a09 dropouts in this cluster (\u223c10 sources per \u0394\u2009<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01), due to either contamination of these dropout samples by lower redshift sources (including low-mass stars), or most likely cosmic variance between cluster fields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, we expect a total of\u00a0\u223c200 <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07 dropouts,\u00a0\u223c70 <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09 dropouts and 5\u201310 dropouts at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a011 in the six HFF, per redshift interval \u0394\u2009<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01, and down to an observed AB magnitude of 29. While the number of high-redshift galaxies detected to this magnitude limit is very similar to that found in blank fields, gravitational magnification, which reaches a factor of\u00a0\u223c1\u20133 mag in the central regions of the HFF images, is the only way to access dropouts at even fainter magnitudes, down to m(AB) = 30\u201332, 2 mag fainter than the limits of the <em>Hubble Ultra Deep Field</em>. It will also increase (by a factor of at least 3) the survey sensitivity for galaxies at the highest redshifts (up to <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a011) at observed magnitudes m(AB)\u2009&lt;\u200927.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We hope that the results of our efforts to calibrate the six HFF cluster lenses, described in this paper and made available to the community via the HFF website, will prove useful for the quantitative scientific exploitation of the HFF initiative and our quest to unravel the mysteries of the epoch of re-ionization.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">JR acknowledges support from the ERC starting grant CALENDS and the CIG grant 294074. MJ, ML and EJ acknowledge the M\u00e9socentre d'Aix-Marseille Universit\u00e9 (project number: 14b030). This has also benefited from the facilities offered by CeSAM (Centre de donneS Astrophysique de Marseille).<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>3</sup></a> ML acknowledges the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) for its support. JPK and HA acknowledge support from the ERC advanced grant LIDA. This work was supported by the Leverhulme Trust (grant number PLP-2011-003) and Science and Technology Facilities Council (grant number ST/F001166/1). PN gratefully acknowledges support from the NSF via grant the AST-1009444.</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.stsci.edu/hst/campaigns/frontier-fields/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Publically available on the dedicated web page</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/\" target=\"_blank\">http://lam.oamp.fr/cesam/</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991973 id=\"91991973\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"citation element-citation\"><span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abell</div> <div class=\"given-names\">G. Pac.</div>pg.\u00a0<div class=\"fpage\">421</div>\u00a0<!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"google-scholar-ref-link\"><a });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n citation</button>\r\n        </form>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <a class=\"close-reveal-modal\" href=\"javascript:;\"><i class=\"icon-general-close\"></i><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Close</span></a>\r\n</div>\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-tools\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxPermissions widget-instance-OUP_Get_Permissions\">\r\n            <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n        <a href=\"https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=OUP&amp;publication=1365-2966&amp;title=Mass%20and%20magnification%20maps%20for%20the%20%26lt%3Bem%26gt%3BHubble%20Space%20Telescope%26lt%3B%2Fem%26gt%3B%20Frontier%20Fields%20clusters%3A%20implications%20for%20high-redshift%20studies&amp;publicationDate=2014-08-14&amp;volumeNum=444&amp;issueNum=1&amp;author=Richard%2C%20Johan%3B%20Jauzac%2C%20Mathilde&amp;startPage=268&amp;endPage=289&amp;contentId=10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstu1395&amp;oa=&amp;copyright=Oxford%20University%20Press&amp;orderBeanReset=True\" class=\"toolbar-search\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-SitePageHeader widget-instance-OUP_ArticleToolbarSearchBox\">\r\n        \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"dropdown-panel-wrap\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin js-nav-dropdown js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution js-nav-dropdown\">\r\n                            University of Utah\r\n                        </a>\r\n\r\n                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                    <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1\">\r\n                            <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nUniversity of Utah\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li           <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f444%2f1%2f268%2f1011074\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n        </ul>\r\n    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                  <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input
