         </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991852 id=\"91991852\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extending over three <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) cycles, the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF) initiative constitutes the largest commitment ever of <em>HST</em> time to the exploration of the distant Universe via gravitational lensing by massive galaxy clusters. Here, we present models of the mass distribution in the six HFF cluster lenses, derived from a joint strong- and weak-lensing analysis anchored by a total of 88 multiple-image systems identified in existing <em>HST</em> data. The resulting maps of the projected mass distribution and of the gravitational magnification effectively calibrate the HFF clusters as gravitational telescopes. Allowing the computation of search areas in the source plane, these maps are provided to the community to facilitate the exploitation of forthcoming HFF data for quantitative studies of the gravitationally lensed population of background galaxies. Our models of the gravitational magnification afforded by the HFF clusters allow us to quantify the lensing-induced boost in sensitivity over blank-field observations and predict that galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a010 and as faint as m(AB) = 32 will be detectable, up to 2 mag fainter than the limit of the <em>Hubble Ultra Deep Field</em>.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: Abell 370&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: Abell 370</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: A1063S&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: A1063S</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: Abell 2744&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: Abell 2744</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J1149.5+2223&quot;\">galaxies clusters: individual: MACS\u00a0J1149.5+2223</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991854 id=\"91991854\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>GRAVITATIONAL LENSING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At the end of the 1980s, the discovery of giant luminous arcs in clusters of galaxies (e.g. Soucail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>) and the realization that they can be explained by gravitational lensing (the bending of light by massive foreground mass concentrations) opened a new and powerful route to studying the distant Universe. Gravitational lensing can be understood as a geometrical mapping of the source plane on to the image plane, a mapping that depends on the surface mass distribution in the deflector and on the angular-diameter distances between the observer and the source, and the lens and the source, respectively (see the review by Kneib &amp; Natarajan\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). For extreme mass concentrations, the mapping is non-linear, producing magnified and highly distorted multiple images of a single background source. Such multiple images have been successfully exploited since the early 1990s (e.g. Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) to constrain the detailed mass distribution in cluster cores as well as to probe the mass distributions of samples of X-ray-selected clusters out to the virial radius (e.g. Smith et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Importantly, lensing also enables the study of distant background galaxies that would be unobservable without the magnification provided by the cluster lens (e.g. Ellis et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Kneib et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Coe et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and offers the tantalizing possibility of measuring the geometry of the Universe through the accurate determination of cosmological distances (Soucail, Kneib &amp; Golse\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The power of clusters as well-calibrated telescopes for studies of the distant Universe has become fully appreciated only in recent years. Highly active areas of research aiming to unveil the characteristics of individual galaxies at 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a05 (e.g. Smail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Livermore et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) or to constrain statistically the properties of the galaxy population at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a05 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) all benefit greatly from gravitational amplification of the respective background sources. State-of-the-art lens-modelling techniques that combine strong-lensing constraints from large numbers of multiple-image systems with high-quality weak-lensing data can measure the mass in cluster cores (and thus the gravitational amplification along a given line of sight) to an accuracy of a few\u00a0per\u2009cent (e.g. Brada\u010d et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The necessary robust and efficient identification of multiple-image systems requires both high angular resolution and colour information. The unparalleled power of <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) for such studies is exemplified by the identification of 42 multiple-image systems in Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) observations of the massive cluster Abell 1689 (Broadhurst et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), 24 of them with measured redshifts from deep Keck and VLT spectroscopy (Limousin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). The ability to obtain spectra for gravitationally amplified galaxies at high redshift is a critical advantage over similar work conducted on non-magnified galaxies in the field, and crucial for the exploration of the end of the Dark Ages, one of the most ambitious and timely quests of present-day astrophysics. Although impressive progress has been made in this research area with the help of moderately deep observations of cluster lenses (e.g. Postman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), a dedicated in-depth observational effort is needed if the scientific promise and potential of gravitational lensing by clusters is to be fully exploited.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This important next step forward is now being taken in the form of the Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF), a recent initiative launched by the Space Telescope Science Institute. As part of the preparations for these unprecedented observations of lensing clusters, five independent teams have analysed the existing imaging and spectroscopic data to provide the community with accurate mass models on each cluster. We describe in this paper the work performed by one of these groups, the CATS (Clusters As TelescopeS) team.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991859 id=\"91991859\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>THE HFF</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields initiative, announced in the spring of 2013, devotes 140 orbits of <em>HST</em> time to deep imaging observations of each of six carefully selected cluster lenses. As a compromise between depth and spectral coverage, each target field will be observed for 20 orbits in each of the <em>F</em>435<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>606<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> filters (all ACS), as well as in the <em>F</em>105<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>125<em>W</em>, <em>F</em>140<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> filters (all WFC3), reaching <em>m</em> \u2248 29 (AB) uniformly in all passbands. The total commitment of 840 orbits of Director's Discretionary Time is spread out over three cycles, starting with Cycle 21, with two clusters being targeted per cycle.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The HFF clusters were selected by an expert team recruited from the extragalactic community, trying to balance scheduling and follow-up constraints with the primary goal of the project: to identify clusters of maximal lensing strength (high gravitational magnification over a large angular area) whose angular size is well matched to the ACS field of view. The resulting list of HFF clusters comprises, in order of observation</p>                        <a id=\"91991862\" scrollto-destination=\"91991862\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl13\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl13\" data-id=\"tbl13\"> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell 2744\u00a0</td><td>0.308\u00a0</td><td>Abell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403\u00a0</td><td>0.396\u00a0</td><td>Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745\u00a0</td><td>0.545\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J1149.5+2223\u00a0</td><td>0.544\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling et\u00a0al.          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91991862\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl13\" data-id=\"tbl13\"> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell 2744\u00a0</td><td>0.308\u00a0</td><td>Abell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403\u00a0</td><td>0.396\u00a0</td><td>Mann &amp; (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell S1063\u00a0</td><td>0.348\u00a0</td><td>Abell, Corwin &amp; Olowin (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell 370\u00a0</td><td>0.375\u00a0</td><td>Abell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Abell 2744\u00a0</td><td>0.308\u00a0</td><td>Abell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403\u00a0</td><td>0.396\u00a0</td><td>Mann &amp; Ebeling (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J0717.5+3745\u00a0</td><td>0.545\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MACS\u00a0J1149.5+2223\u00a0</td><td>0.544\u00a0</td><td>Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell S1063\u00a0</td><td>0.348\u00a0</td><td>Abell, Corwin &amp; Olowin (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1989</a>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Abell 370\u00a0</td><td>0.375\u00a0</td><td>Abell (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1958</a>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/91991862\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">More information on the HFF initiative, both scientific and technical, can be found on the <em>HST</em> Frontier Fields homepage.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\"><sup>1</sup></a></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All six HFF clusters have previously been targeted with <em>HST</em>. These observations were instrumental in the selection of the respective clusters for the HFF project as highly efficient gravitational lenses. Unlike A370, the first cluster lens to be discovered (Soucail et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), most of the remaining HFF targets are much more recent discoveries made by the Massive Cluster Survey (MACS, Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). As a result, many of the existing <em>HST</em> observations of these fields were obtained only in the past few years and could thus take advantage of <em>HST</em>'s current state-of-the-art instruments. Further details are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl10\" data-open=\"tbl10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> which lists all imaging observations performed with broad-band filters on ACS and WFC3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the outlines of the area targeted by the planned HFF observations overlaid on the existing <em>HST</em> imaging data. Note that, in all cases, the blank flanking fields fall outside the area covered by the existing data; hence, the gravitational magnification induced at the location of the flanking fields by either the clusters themselves, or by large-scale structure in their immediate vicinity, can presently not be constrained with <em>HST</em> data.</p>                        <a id=\"91991866\" scrollto-destination=\"91991866\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=30yDnN8i4YM2wDKzAe2Hb865-6~FFKUIABrWpeeyTlVHxstz8cjMfA7kwqX46btPuX375IHsewDQ0Gk5hBLvKut1GlzivU7ajUX76T2-iw4ML0g-iWjICO-wFnaMjIPf~ZKx9EjGWn0ABxY-F-RgNmyVIOIyeuQHd~RXWSW~~umLG3zmYk~W4M89S1yfpSNxZmFv5XC2~Mtc5t60ojTNfIlYSlGdkK77zhGYjlUz6Z4F9tQV6xVtpRPApUr-gM~58RIrzi1h68JmIJt5bhMpW4zIkA8QxRBjbFPb54IIEQBWvhlV6GKLaiY39jqxZT205Tb~BTzHBoBxgHgv8~W3JQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour images (F435W+F606W+F814W) of the archival HST data for the HFF (except for A370 where we show F475W+F625W+F814W). Overlaid in blue (red) are the apertures of the planned, deep HFF observations with ACS (WFC3). In all cases, the parallel flanking fields \u2013 which fall well outside the depicted area \u2013 have not been previously imaged with HST. The images shown are trimmed to the regions in which data in at least two filters are available whose central wavelengths differ by at least 150\u00a0\u00c5, thus providing colour information suitable for the identification of multiple-image systems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991866/stu1395fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991866\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=mFoanv9NIFcga9HoLYNNx2uMBkbrFoZ2eUXMs76uNuUE5HgNSrybjsk7aLRFQr89KJFbNcNT~HdkIUW-85YOoqQ2gFY-CI6KSWCgVsH2hqZQQgKix1ibxPcd~ygvwNjHId-zznUab6letR2uP78II3OjE6sYOeaYwgpt5OorZQRU01fKo6~FBIZsL-UBiIgzOQGcY6KP5~M1Gi1sll5L-n02OSNp9g3JRYLMSCIOVxjLdlXikASwAGNiOmEhpsG3qYBHiQIMUEvlxx9ZmJhhK71FhcxBIJ~XE2KOGVpp7q7SQXVuaw7h7yAXuo3OK1935ZFdaa~SM8dJYXM8CIYu7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991866&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour images (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) of the archival <em>HST</em> data for the HFF (except for A370 where we show <em>F</em>475<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>625<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>). Overlaid in blue (red) are the apertures of the planned, deep HFF observations with ACS (WFC3). In all cases, the parallel flanking fields \u2013 which fall well outside the depicted area \u2013 have not been previously imaged with <em>HST</em>. The images shown are trimmed to the regions in which data in at least two filters are available whose central wavelengths differ by at least 150\u00a0\u00c5, thus providing colour information suitable for the identification of multiple-image systems.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=30yDnN8i4YM2wDKzAe2Hb865-6~FFKUIABrWpeeyTlVHxstz8cjMfA7kwqX46btPuX375IHsewDQ0Gk5hBLvKut1GlzivU7ajUX76T2-iw4ML0g-iWjICO-wFnaMjIPf~ZKx9EjGWn0ABxY-F-RgNmyVIOIyeuQHd~RXWSW~~umLG3zmYk~W4M89S1yfpSNxZmFv5XC2~Mtc5t60ojTNfIlYSlGdkK77zhGYjlUz6Z4F9tQV6xVtpRPApUr-gM~58RIrzi1h68JmIJt5bhMpW4zIkA8QxRBjbFPb54IIEQBWvhlV6GKLaiY39jqxZT205Tb~BTzHBoBxgHgv8~W3JQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour images (F435W+F606W+F814W) of the archival HST data for the HFF (except for A370 where we show F475W+F625W+F814W). Overlaid in blue (red) are the apertures of the planned, deep HFF observations with ACS (WFC3). In all cases, the parallel flanking fields \u2013 which fall well outside the depicted area \u2013 have not been previously imaged with HST. The images shown are trimmed to the regions in which data in at least two filters are available whose central wavelengths differ by at least 150\u00a0\u00c5, thus providing colour information suitable for the identification of multiple-image systems.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991866/stu1395fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991866\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=mFoanv9NIFcga9HoLYNNx2uMBkbrFoZ2eUXMs76uNuUE5HgNSrybjsk7aLRFQr89KJFbNcNT~HdkIUW-85YOoqQ2gFY-CI6KSWCgVsH2hqZQQgKix1ibxPcd~ygvwNjHId-zznUab6letR2uP78II3OjE6sYOeaYwgpt5OorZQRU01fKo6~FBIZsL-UBiIgzOQGcY6KP5~M1Gi1sll5L-n02OSNp9g3JRYLMSCIOVxjLdlXikASwAGNiOmEhpsG3qYBHiQIMUEvlxx9ZmJhhK71FhcxBIJ~XE2KOGVpp7q7SQXVuaw7h7yAXuo3OK1935ZFdaa~SM8dJYXM8CIYu7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991866&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour images (<em>F</em>435<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>) of the archival <em>HST</em> data for the HFF (except for A370 where we show <em>F</em>475<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>625<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>). Overlaid in blue (red) are the apertures of the planned, deep HFF observations with ACS (WFC3). In all cases, the parallel flanking fields \u2013 which fall well outside the depicted area \u2013 have not been previously imaged with <em>HST</em>. The images shown are trimmed to the regions in which data in at least two filters are available whose central wavelengths differ by at least 150\u00a0\u00c5, thus providing colour information suitable for the identification of multiple-image systems.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991867 id=\"91991867\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>STRONG-LENSING FEATURES</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991868 id=\"91991868\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>Identifications</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now review, for each cluster, the associations of multiple images found in these <em>HST</em> images prior to HFF observations and used to constrain the strong-lensing models (see Section\u00a04). We adopt the term \u2018system\u2019 for a set of multiple images arising from the same source, and the notation XY to describe image Y of system X (see Tables\u00a01\u20136 and Figs\u00a01\u20138 for each cluster in turn). We build our identification of multiple systems from earlier published lists of multiple images (identified either by our own or by other groups). For clusters having such a large number of constraints, our parametric analysis is quite sensitive to wrong identifications: we therefore added iteratively new systems and used the current model to predict additional counter-images. In a few cases, where the identification was ambiguous between multiple candidates, these counter-images were not added as constraints.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991870 id=\"91991870\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>Abell 2744</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">An earlier strong-lensing analysis of this cluster was previously published by Merten et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), who identified 11 systems and a total of 34 images. We build from these 11 systems and identify seven additional, convincing systems of multiple images (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), leading to a total of 55 images. The majority of these new systems are located around the core of the cluster, but three new systems are identified around several sub-clumps (galaxy-scale) groups close to the north and north-west limits of the ACS coverage (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). These sub-clumps were identified as \u2018N\u2019 and \u2018NW\u2019, respectively, in Merten et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"91991872\" scrollto-destination=\"91991872\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=aQUSRknDVCz6HOMcZdzvEoDmnbGPV-K0zZHqjrifP4rBRzJbmrWBqk4IHSVljdOfsnHkU7eHiZ~OvVJRk1UL57upGn9wKyd7SOgksUrf0S9FsQ9SwW9xJmoLWIw-Eu4UyF4-kySt7BXIw-3Bs2~FPLPt0DZcNGTzqHxMGU2eBNOJzLHcUm7SgWAWs9OVbfVhLYvUVM1vmJvul6UGlpPWwUt~PW42YkyiSEtsHEvgoHaFPjUlJw97gYdSiRUTh826IRzzuWHLKTNeuiCHGC6-KvJqYvtcNsUsw~YQ29ALzzcSy57KYSVtDgX7qMdJGmznR2iEjtI4y808279ZAAhcIQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour image of A2744 as obtained with HST/ACS (F435W+F606W+F814W). Strong-lensing features as listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> are labelled.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to Merten et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), we removed image 8.3 from our list of constraints, as its colours and location do not match well for a multiple system (in particular, the geometry should be similar to system 3). In addition, we do not find any convincing counter-image (third image of a triple \u2018fold\u2019 configuration) for systems 14, 15, and 18.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991875 id=\"91991875\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>MACS\u00a0J0416</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) presented a strong-lensing model with 23 systems identified in this cluster in the new CLASH (Postman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) data, producing in total 70 images. Due to the very elongated nature of the cluster mass distribution (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), all systems appear as triply imaged configurations. Among the total list of 23 systems, 10 systems and 36 images were considered by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) as less robust candidate multiple images.</p>                        <a id=\"91991877\" scrollto-destination=\"91991877\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=AoH~uycMC7eTED84d38cFI8IHClwjI6C1VlIbQbuqDx-j7D4snnbIHVQleTgqKbTGvfDkpGj9CaRlwBDZeCE0UEiJGtGZO6aX5zrv9x9h~xF8HWxeuzMmhj1M~h6LkBmvxzcZq0pJPdCdRmbMcwbed8ZAzrdxpCduMDncXHl1n-KS4I0oiCtpIRXKfCCISEUa1m9h~xX-j4pcnN~ZgLnZzLmHRZ02kFWznrz6ZBeQei4BIMrn2JaHCKxNV-Gpmf~753BKPhyRY4uuPsFtAlIYH7fpsGxTYWHrhF4LzTCCHya~B0QY9hzLxKDOQr0OEgzAaF4PcpSzD1XWGhoCzgIzQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as Fig.\u00a02 but for Abell 370 and filter combination F625W+F814W+F160W.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/91991881/stu1395fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"91991881\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=Yur1l2t6dXhqcnlKSwwoMKos3d7uK4AidTTS4Vuc0NVqj1qtb-Fi09YBWvJWhhjncIhpyNLoX3Nwvgn2d-ApuDdKZxD~-0Xc-Ak261TKDTbUkM~BHxJa8gmnxEUQNwhLTjDF0f~SI1ThXpqdEbFwd9mmjV~SVgODkkfynEqdHj~tmGX9jcnfSS4K3sr-Hs9R7tmJnpUM~S7gpc3PIyfw2RbMk4e6Bib9P3Yl09ORv8pahOMoYWBmN1oemAonHPfAQe1qJy1sRLmIDMrIGB2xlbvcFsYG2lcddMB00A6BulVtdeaYchBhnXAazczP0dEtJwTra0wv86t-aU7wKUcoCQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991881&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Same as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> but for Abell 370 and filter combination <em>F</em>625<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>814<em>W</em>+<em>F</em>160<em>W</em>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have built from this list of strong-lensing features and selected only the most robust systems and a few candidate systems showing clear counter-images based on our preliminary strong-lensing analysis (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). New spectroscopic information (see Section\u00a03.2.2) was also incorporated to help with this selection. In total, our final list contains 17 systems and 47 images. We do not identify a reliable (unambiguous) third image for systems 5, 8, 9, and 12.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991883 id=\"91991883\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-3>MACS\u00a0J0717</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The set of multiply imaged systems used in the analysis of MACS\u00a0J0717 mainly follows the one described in Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), with a few exceptions that we discuss here. The location of image 1.5 has been revisited, following Medezinski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). System 2 has been removed from the analysis, after discussion between the different teams, given its faintness.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, we added new spectroscopic redshifts measurements, in agreement with our previous estimates, obtained by the GLASS survey (Schmidt et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) for three multiple systems (4, 6, and 12). Finally, Vanzella et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) recently measured a spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06.4 for two galaxies which we confirm to be multiply imaged with three images identified based on the mass model. We add this new constraint as system 19.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991886 id=\"91991886\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-4>MACS\u00a0J1149</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The set of multiply imaged systems used in the analysis of MACS\u00a0J1149 is based on the one presented by Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), with the addition of six new systems as proposed by Zitrin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>): systems 5, 6, 7, 8, 13, and 14.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991888 id=\"91991888\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-5>Abell S1063</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify in this cluster 14 multiply imaged systems, all in a configuration of three images except for system 6 which shows as a quad (Boone et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The robustness of these systems has been checked with a dedicated spectroscopic follow-up (Section\u00a03.2.5). While this paper was being written, Monna et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) presented their own identifications, partially overlapping with our own list: we identify four additional systems and they identified two additional candidate systems which appear much fainter and less robust. In total, our list comprises 41 images of the 14 systems, as we do not find an unambiguous counterpart for systems 10 and 12.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991890 id=\"91991890\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-6>Abell 370</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our strong-lensing analysis builds from the work published in Richard et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>), where we identified nine multiply imaged systems (as well as a faint radial arc, system 10). New <em>HST</em>/WFC3 images have been taken since this publication and allowed us to identify two additional systems. In total, we use 11 systems producing 34 images (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991892 id=\"91991892\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>Spectroscopy of strong-lensing features</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Whenever possible, we use spectroscopic redshifts of multiply imaged systems to constrain the lens model. This information is important since the source redshifts are degenerate with the absolute values of the model parameters characterizing the mass distribution. All our models are anchored by spectroscopic redshifts for two to eight different multiple-image systems. We use spectroscopic redshifts from the literature, results shared among the different HFF mass modelling groups, and values obtained by us as part of dedicated spectroscopic follow-up observations. In the latter case, we provide below the details of the observations, data reduction, and analysis of these spectra.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991894 id=\"91991894\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-1>A2744</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We targeted the core of this cluster as part of our VLT/FOcal Reducer and low dispersion Spectrograph (FORS2) spectroscopic follow-up of submillimeter sources from the Herschel Lensing Survey (Egami et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). 10 multiple-image systems were observed in Multi-Object Spectroscopy (MOS) mode for a total of 2\u00a0h exposure time during the night of 2011 September 3 (ESO programme 087.B-0560(A), PI: Richard). We used a slit width of 1\u00a0arcsec, the GRIS_300V grism and the <em>GG</em>345 filter to cover the wavelength range from 4300 to 9200 \u00c5, albeit at low resolution (<em>R</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a0500\u20131000) and a dispersion of 2 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Of the strongly lensed sources targeted, redshifts could be secured for image A2744-4.3 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.58, through strong Lyman \u03b1 emission (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>), in agreement with the photometric redshift of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a03.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3 reported by Merten et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The spectrum of object 6.1 was found to feature a single narrow emission line at 5760 \u00c5 on top of a very blue continuum. The absence of other emission lines in the wavelength range covered agrees with C\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.019, which is compatible with our prediction based on a preliminary lens model.</p>                        <a id=\"91991897\" scrollto-destination=\"91991897\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/stu1395fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&Signature=z~k0LypX6sLoZBRljnyRTR9U6YBuOSoekhy55QCQZmvXbhJtXBc7vK2rSGhRKfAkwiduvTaAzeqQCZPExwLOeik7hQREBTJsPPzPyDjZ1xXwxO7hafaETo-qIyAIFewidsvxHLi6hFzPoql-Fh8rmCxAaek5arD8l6oHyMC186z9~5M6cnnQ0cUcB-Qfc~twhllENFxPg3DlQ0ppKMAfXVF0w-muvS35nraSKqNNLCERUOp8zw0qRfpn7MT9do4it8DQjucWJf3luHzYGa8MRhYknbZiliMu~sMiM8N8oMHQpb6Y6AJiRqC7cPHwXgRtib6RBgUyuZCpv7kxaY7rDw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=91991897&ar=1011074&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stu1395fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Example of extracted spectra showing identified emission lines in multiple images.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991898 id=\"91991898\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2>MACS\u00a0J0416</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use spectroscopic redshifts for seven systems in MACS\u00a0J0416.1\u22122403 (systems 2, 3, 7, 10, 13, 14, and 17) obtained as part of VLT programme 186.A-0798 (Balestra et\u00a0al., in preparation; Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and shared among the different HFF mass modelling groups. We also include spectroscopic redshifts for system 1, published by our group in Christensen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991900 id=\"91991900\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-3>MACS\u00a0J0717</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the analysis by Limousin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which presents our earlier observations on arc spectroscopy, one new spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06.4 has been measured for system 19, as described previously. We use spectroscopic redshifts for six systems in total (systems 1, 3, 13, 14, 15, and 19), ranging from <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.850 to 6.4.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991902 id=\"91991902\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-4>MACS\u00a0J1149</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the analysis by Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), no new spectroscopic redshifts have been measured in MACS\u00a0J1149. We use spectroscopic redshifts for three systems (systems 1 to 3) at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.490, 1.894, and 2.497. We refer to Smith et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) for details regarding arc spectroscopy.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991904 id=\"91991904\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-5>AS1063</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have obtained spectroscopy of images 1.1 and 1.2 using multi-object spectroscopy with Magellan/LDSS3 on the night of 2009 October 11. We used LDSS3 with 1.0\u00a0arcsec-width slits and the VPH-All grism, which altogether provide a resolution of 650 and a dispersion of 1.9 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> while covering the wavelength range 3800\u20139900 \u00c5. The seeing was good (0.7\u20130.9\u00a0arcsec) during the 5.4 ks total exposure time of these observations. The LDSS3 spectra were calibrated, combined and extracted using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">idl</span> routines. Both images AS1063-1.1 and 1.2 show a strong emission line at wavelength 8307 \u00c5 and other fainter emission lines, compatible with [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [Ne\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] at a spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.229\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.005.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additional spectroscopy was obtained on VLT/FORS2 the night of 2013 August 21, as part of the ESO programme 291.A-5027 (PI:Richard). We designed a multislit spectroscopic mask covering images 2.1, 3.1, 4.3, 6.2, 6.3, 6.4 in the strong-lensing region and we obtained 4.5 ks of exposure time under bright time but good seeing conditions (0.8\u20130.9\u00a0arcsec). We used the 600z grism, <em>OG</em>590 order filter and 1.0\u00a0arcsec-wide slits to cover the wavelength range 7200-9800 \u00c5 at a resolution\u00a0\u223c1500\u20131900 and a dispersion 1.6 \u00c5 pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>. The FORS2 spectra were reduced using version 4.9.11 of the FORS2 data reduction software, and combined using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">idl</span> routines. Both 2D and extracted spectra were visually inspected for faint emission lines and traces of continuum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We identified a clear emission line doublet (also visible in single exposures) for images AS1063-2.1, 3.1, and 4.3, corresponding to [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] nebular line at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.429, 1.398, and 1.260, respectively (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). All three slits covering system 6 (AS1063-6.2, 6.3, and 6.4) show an identical spectrum with a strong asymmetric emission line peaking at \u03bb\u00a0=\u00a08642 \u00c5, which is the signature of Lyman \u03b1 emission at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06.107 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>). This confirms both the association of the three images as well as the high-redshift nature of this source (see also Boone et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All the redshifts measured in this cluster are in perfect agreement with estimations from a preliminary model of the mass distribution.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=91991909 id=\"91991909\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-6>Abell 370</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We targeted the core of this cluster in a VLT/FORS2 spectroscopic programme meant to estimate cosmological parameters from strongly lensed features (Jullo et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Nine multiply imaged systems were observed in MOS mode during a total of 7.5\u00a0h exposure time in the nights between 2011 September 22 and 26 (ESO programme 087.A-0326(A), PI: Jullo). We have used 1\u2009arcsec-width slits with the GRIS300V grism (2.5\u00a0h exposure time) to search for Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission or other UV features, and the GRIS600z grism and <em>OG</em>590 filter (5\u00a0h exposure time) to detect objects in the redshift range 1\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a02. The dispersion per pixel is 1.63 \u00c5 in the red, and 3.3 \u00c5 in the blue. Among the strongly lensed sources targeted, we were able to measure the redshifts of image A370-6.3 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.063, through a clear detection of the [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet. We also detect faint emission lines for image 3.1 and 3.2, which would correspond to [O\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [Ne\u00a0<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.421, and a faint emission line for image 4.1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.275 with the blue grism. The redshifts measured for systems 4 and 6 agree with the lens model predictions. However, the redshift of system 3 gives a very large \u03c7<sup>2</sup> to this system. Therefore, we preferred not to use the two most uncertain redshifts (systems 3 and 4) as constraints in our lens model (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Additional follow-up spectroscopy would help us confirm these two redshifts.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991911 id=\"91991911\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>Weak-lensing constraints</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The background galaxy catalogues for the six clusters were derived following the method presented in (Jauzac et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>). Therefore, we here give a brief summary of the different steps.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The weak-lensing analysis is based on shape measurements in the ACS/<em>F</em>814<em>W</em> band. Following a method developed for the analysis of data obtained for the COSMOS survey, and described in (Leauthaud et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>), the <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> photometry package (Bertin &amp; Arnouts\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) is used for the detection of the sources, using the <em>\u2018Hot\u2013Cold\u2019</em> method (Rix et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>). This detection configuration combines an optimal detection of the brightest objects (<em>cold</em> step), and of the faintest ones (<em>hot</em> step). The resulting catalogue is then cleaned by removing spurious, duplicate detections, and any sources in the vicinity of stars or saturated pixels. The star\u2013galaxy classification is performed using a standard MAG<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\_$|</span>AUTO-MU<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\_$|</span>MAX plane selection (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a> &amp; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a> for more details). Finally, to overcome the pattern-dependent correlations introduced by the drizzling process between neighbouring pixels, which artificially reduce the noise level of co-added drizzled images, we apply the remedy used by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">L07</a>: simply scaling up the noise level in each pixel by the same constant <em>F</em><sub><em>A</em></sub> \u2248 0.316, defined by Casertano et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since only galaxies behind the clusters are gravitationally lensed, the presence of cluster members dilutes the observed shear and reduces the significance of all quantities derived from it (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a> for a more detailed discussion). Therefore, the identification and the removal of the contaminating unlensed galaxies is crucial. Thanks to the existing <em>HST</em> data for all six clusters, a minimum of two colours is available for each of them. Therefore, following the methodology described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>, we used the existing spectroscopic and photometric redshifts (Owers et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ebeling, Ma &amp; Barrett\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to calibrate a colour\u2013colour selection to identify the foreground galaxies and cluster members (the combination of filters used for each cluster is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) .</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The measure of galaxy shapes is done using the RRG method (Rhodes, Refregier &amp; Groth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), which was developed for the analysis of data obtained from space, and is thus ideally suited for use with a small, diffraction-limited point spread function (PSF) as it decreases the noise on the shear estimators by correcting each moment of the PSF linearly, and only dividing them at the very end to compute an ellipticity. The last step of the weak-lensing catalogue construction consists of applying lensing cuts, i.e. to exclude galaxies whose shape parameters are ill-determined, and will thus increase the noise in the shear measurements more than add to the shear signal. More details can be found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">J12</a>. Finally, we assume the redshift distribution of Smail &amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) for the background galaxies with shear measurement. The final density of background galaxies we obtained for each clusters are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl7\" data-open=\"tbl7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=91991916 id=\"91991916\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>METHODOLOGY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We combine strong-lensing and weak-lensing constraints to model the mass distribution in each cluster. Following our successful strategy from previous lensing work (e.g. Limousin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>,\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Richard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>), we adopt a parametric model combining both large-scale (cluster or group size) mass clumps as well as galaxy-scale mass clumps. In the following, we describe the selection of cluster members across the ACS field of view, the choice of model parameters, and their optimization.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=91991918 id=\"91991918\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>Galaxy catalogues</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We create object catalogues for each HFF cluster using <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) for the areas shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, i.e. the region within which <em>HST</em> imaging data are available in at least three well separated passbands. Using the <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> images (<em>F</em>625<em>W</em> in the case of A370) as the primary detection band, we run <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> in dual-image mode on the images in each passband. The resulting catalogues are combined to create for each cluster a master catalogue of objects. Star\u2013galaxy separation is performed by identifying stars in two separate parameter spaces, namely peak surface brightness versus flux, and half-light radius versus flux. We remove from our catalogues all stars and all spurious sources found either to feature a higher peak surface brightness or to be more compact than stars. To improve the robustness of this procedure (the small area covered by the existing <em>HST</em> images of the HFF contains very few stars for each individual field), we perform the star\u2013galaxy separation on a combined object catalogue for all six fields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting catalogues of galaxies are then used to establish colour\u2013colour cuts for the identification of likely cluster members. We examine the distribution of galaxies in both colour\u2013magnitude diagrams and in colour\u2013colour space (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub> versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>), highlighting the loci of spectroscopically confirmed cluster members. We then define probable cluster members to be those galaxies that fall within 3\u03c3 of a linear model of the cluster red sequence in both the (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> and the (<em>m</em><sub>F435W</sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) versus <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows the galaxies selected by this process as well as all spectroscopically confirmed cluster members. We compile the latter from various catalogues of spectroscopic redshifts: for A2744, we consult Owers et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>); for MACS\u00a0J0416, MACS\u00a0J0717, and MACS\u00a0J1149, we use the redshifts published by Ebeling et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); and for AS1063 and A370, we rely on spectroscopic redshifts compiled in the NASA Extragalactic Database. We also use redshifts obtained by Balestra et\u00a0al. (2013, in preparation) for MACS\u00a0J0416. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, the galaxies selected by the dual red-sequence criterion fall into a well-defined triangular region of (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>435<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>) versus (<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>606<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>) colour\u2013colour space. Galaxies featuring luminosities exceeding <em>M</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.01\u2009<em>L</em>* are included in our strong-lensing mass model as small-scale perturbers (see following section).</p>                        <a id=\"91991921\" scrollto-destination=\"91991921\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/444/1/10.1093_mnras_stu1395/1/m_stu1395fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639265445&amp;Signature=vYtNCsK8lC~wIwYwaJKV~gGZMbayW3aZHMr8d6y5JPk4gAg5yq-KI2BDGol0w~KSCSUYVBXMsh6RusL5su4TOCW8nCTk1soj7klqW2Qzi5P~4RCMAblXhOjMXNm6zRBm8MYw1scReJG-jmYInTpW4ca45rxSeF3hhlX5zfAjvPottgzAxS15fNEBCkIiu8uloZGpps7eZa-wUp9wDbxLVeY6yK4c56CSeNUTTUYluDSg0zNdk2TXXwuem26ce~v4UejoDYZmbJnxXVeb-AbLkAlx7YNwWvu-zf7-M3TO4xv~EN0GgFRiJwugfMy2-IzMOq6liP-~X4rUuS31CZ5ejQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour\u2013colour diagram for galaxies in the A2744 field, as defined in Fig.\u00a01.
